# Philistine captivity of the Ark

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/DuraSyn-
WB4-Ark_and_Temple_of_Dagon.jpg/300px-DuraSyn-
WB4-Ark_and_Temple_of_Dagon.jpg)](/wiki/File:DuraSyn-
WB4-Ark_and_Temple_of_Dagon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DuraSyn-WB4-Ark_and_Temple_of_Dagon.jpg "Enlarge")

[Fresco](/wiki/Fresco "Fresco") of the Philistine captivity of the ark, in the
[Dura-Europos synagogue](/wiki/Dura-Europos_synagogue "Dura-Europos
synagogue").

The **Philistine captivity of the Ark** was an episode described in the
biblical history of the [Israelites](/wiki/Israelite "Israelite"), in which
the [Ark of the covenant](/wiki/Ark_of_the_covenant "Ark of the covenant") was
in the possession of the [Philistines](/wiki/Philistines "Philistines"), who
had captured it after defeating the Israelites in a battle at a location
between [Eben-ezer](/wiki/Eben-ezer "Eben-ezer"), where the Israelites
encamped, and [Aphek](/wiki/Aphek_\(biblical\) "Aphek \(biblical\)") (probably
[Antipatris](/wiki/Antipatris "Antipatris")), where the Philistines encamped.

The ark narrative does not include any mention of
[Samuel](/wiki/Samuel_\(Biblical_figure\) "Samuel \(Biblical figure\)"); Bill
Arnold suggests that it is "in order to celebrate the power of Yahweh's
ark."[1] Many scholars put 1 Samuel 4 - 6 together with 2 Samuel 6 and believe
that it reflects an old source that was eventually incorporated into the
History of David's Rise or into the later [Deuteronomistic
History](/wiki/Deuteronomist "Deuteronomist").[2]

According to [1 Samuel](/wiki/Books_of_Samuel "Books of Samuel") 4, prior to
the battle the Ark had been residing at the ancient sanctuary of
[Shiloh](/wiki/Shiloh_\(Biblical_city\) "Shiloh \(Biblical city\)"), but was
brought out by the Israelites in hope of victory in the war. The Israelites
suffered a significant defeat; [Hophni and Phinehas](/wiki/Hophni_and_Phinehas
"Hophni and Phinehas"), sons of the [High Priest](/wiki/Kohen_Gadol "Kohen
Gadol") [Eli](/wiki/Eli_\(Bible\) "Eli \(Bible\)"), were killed and the ark
was captured. The news of the ark's capture was such a shock to Eli that he
fell off his chair and died, while [Phinehas' wife](/wiki/Wife_of_Phinehas
"Wife of Phinehas") died in childbirth as she heard the news, giving birth to
[Ichabod](/wiki/Ichabod "Ichabod"), whose name means "Where is the glory?"
[Robert Alter](/wiki/Robert_Alter "Robert Alter") argues that 1 Samuel 4:22
should be translated as "Glory is _exiled_ from Israel," and that the story of
the Philistine captivity of the ark is one of [exile](/wiki/Exile "Exile").[3]
[Peter Leithart](/wiki/Peter_Leithart "Peter Leithart") suggests that Israel
deserved to go into exile, but the ark did so instead: "Yahweh went into
exile, taking on the curse of the covenant for His people, and while in exile
He fought for them and defeated the gods of Philistia."[4]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/The_plague_of_ashdod_1630.jpg/300px-
The_plague_of_ashdod_1630.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_plague_of_ashdod_1630.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_plague_of_ashdod_1630.jpg "Enlarge")

[Nicolas Poussin](/wiki/Nicolas_Poussin "Nicolas Poussin"), _The Plague of
Ashdod_.

1 Samuel 5 and 6 describe the Philistines as having to move the Ark to several
parts of their territory, as tumours or [hemorrhoids](/wiki/Hemorrhoids
"Hemorrhoids") ("emerods") afflicted the people in each town to which it was
taken: [Ashdod](/wiki/Ashdod "Ashdod"), then [Gath](/wiki/Gath_\(city\) "Gath
\(city\)"), then [Ekron](/wiki/Ekron "Ekron"). The
[Septuagint](/wiki/Septuagint "Septuagint") adds that "[mice](/wiki/Mouse
"Mouse") sprang up in the midst of their country".[5] Stirrup points out that
the "severity of the punishments increases through the passage": tumours in
Ashdod (vv. 6-8), extensive tumours and panic in Gath, which had volunteered
to take on the Ark (vv. 9,10a), and tumours on those who did not die and
deathly panic in Ekron, which was 'volunteered' to take the Ark (vv.
10b-12).[6] The text explicitly ascribes the plague to "[Yahweh](/wiki/Yahweh
"Yahweh")'s hand" (1 Samuel 5:6).

In Ashdod, when the Ark was placed in the temple of [Dagon](/wiki/Dagon
"Dagon"), the statue of Dagon was found [prostrate](/wiki/Prostration
"Prostration") in front of the Ark the next morning; after the statue of Dagon
was restored to its place, it was again found prostrate the next morning, and
this time its head and hands had also been broken off.

Leithart provides a number of parallels between the Philistine captivity of
the Ark and the [Plagues of Egypt](/wiki/Plagues_of_Egypt "Plagues of Egypt")
in the [Book of Exodus](/wiki/Book_of_Exodus "Book of Exodus"). The ark brings
about plagues, humbles the gods of the Philistines and returns full of
treasure.[7] In fact, the Philistine diviners refer to the events of the
[Exodus](/wiki/The_Exodus "The Exodus") in 1 Samuel 6:6. On the advice of
these [diviners](/wiki/Divination "Divination") about how to end the plagues,
the Philistines made a guilt offering of five golden tumors and five gold mice
(representing the five Philistine rulers). They then placed the gold along
with the ark on a cart drawn by two milch cows, who head straight for Israel
and do not waver. The ark stops at [Beth Shemesh](/wiki/Beit_Shemesh "Beit
Shemesh") before finding a more permanent home at [Kiriath-
Jearim](/wiki/Kiriath-Jearim "Kiriath-Jearim").
